quoteFirst: At 7.55 A.M. we started ahead. At 8.20 A.M. it was found that we could not handle the ship by the stern; stopped and attempted to take the line forward. Before it could be made fast, the ship settled so rapidly that the crew was obliged to abandon her, and we hauled the tow-line on board. At 8.54 A.M. the bow of the _Californian_ went down, apparently resting on bottom. At
quoteLast: the stern disappeared and _Corsair_ proceeded. While waiting we hoisted two of the _Californian’s_ boats on board.
title: The Corsair in the war zone
author: Paine, Ralph Delahaye, 1871-1925

quoteFirst: I again gave orders to abandon the ship, which was done, and the _Californian_ soon began to sink rapidly, going down bow first until the stern was almost perpendicular. Later the ship slowly righted and the stern disappeared entirely at
title: The Corsair in the war zone
author: Paine, Ralph Delahaye, 1871-1925

quoteFirst: “You haven’t got time, Chick,” Bert protested. “It’s
title: Right Half Hollins
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Crump, Leslie, 1894-1962 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: I followed him with my eyes, and it was to my agreeable surprise that I heard him crying to me, ‘All is well; fear not!’ though it was not without a species of jealousy that I saw him mounting up to the height of 1,400 or 1,500 feet. The balloon, after having run a distance of 3,600 feet in a horizontal direction, began gently to descend at
quoteLast: , at the village of Inieres, after having travelled 42,000 feet from the point of departure. When it had touched the ground it bumped up again two or three feet. M.
title:
Wonderful Balloon Ascents; Or, The Conquest of the Skies
A History of Balloons and Balloon Voyages
author: Marion, Fulgence

quoteFirst: "Fourteen minutes to nine," said he.  "At nine o'clock I shall drive alone to No. 300 Portland Place, in a taxi.  At
quoteLast: Coverdale and Arbuthnot will follow.  They will ask for the Ambassador, Coverdale giving the name of General Drago, and Arbuthnot the name of Count Alexis Zbynska.
title: Mrs. Fitz
author: Snaith, J. C. (John Collis), 1876-1936

quoteFirst: "Tuesday, 12th June. At 6 the boat came on board with wood and an account that James Cavanagh a prisoner who was sent to cut wood had run into the Brush and that a party of men had been in pursuit of him and could not find him and he was left behind: at 1/
quoteLast: a heavy squall: gave the vessel more cable: found her driving in shore very fast: the gale continuing and a heavy sea. Set the top-sail, main-sail and fore-top-stay sail and cut the cable, not being able to get anchor on account of vessel driving so fast: the anchor was lost, 120 fathoms of cable.
title:
The Logbooks of the Lady Nelson
With the journal of her first commander Lieutenant James Grant
author: Lee, Ida, 1865-1943

title:
The Scientific Tourist through Ireland
in which the traveller is directed to the principal objects of antiquity, art, science & the picturesque
author: Walford, Thomas, 1752-1833
